note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up of mitral valve repair done on 8/3/2020.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes, asthma, and negative cardiac work-up for coronary artery disease.


REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
Respiratory: Reports shallow breathing.
VITALS

Melissa Sanchez is doing well. She is being seen today for status post-hole stent placement. At her previous follow-up, we felt that she was doing well from a cardiac standpoint and recommended she continue with the same medication, lasix, and atenolol.


objective_exam: #####EMPTY#####

Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion.
Breathing is normal.
Cardiovascular: Rhythm is irregularly irregular. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Musculoskeletal: Trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities.
Psychological: Nontender to palpation.
Schedule appointment with the cardiologist for follow-up today at 10:00.
Exam of the heart: Regular monitoring of rhythm and rhythm.
Gastrointestinal: No rebound bowel sounds.
VITALS: Regular rate and rhythm of heart.


RESULTS

ECG taken on 12/26/2020 reveals atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response, t wave inversion anteriorly. There is no significant changes compared to the previous study.
Impression: Mitral valve repair done on 8/3/2020. Melanie Sanchez has a history of mitral regurgitation and atrial Fibrillation, history of diabetes, asthma, and recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac work-up for coronary artery disease. She is taking Coumadin 4 mg mg, lasix and atenolol. Her sedation is controlled with sedation.


ASSESSMENT

Melissa Sanchez is status post mitral valve repair done on 8/3/2020.

Atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response, t wave inversion anteriorly.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient’s previous clinical examination demonstrated no significant changes. However, she did present with elevated ejection fraction, murmur, abdominal pain, and a right ventricular tachycardia murmur. Her echocardiogram from 12/26/2020 shows no change in her mitral regurgitation nor her left ventricular function. We will continue to monitor her. She will follow up with me in 6 months to check on her.
INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up as needed.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

New patient note.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 100-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of a new worrisome heart murmur. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath, but reports severe leg pain that has been going on for about a month. The patient was seen by her cardiologist last week, who ordered a chest x-ray. She started taking pain pills for her legs, which have improved her symptoms. She also reports swelling in her ankles, which she has noticed for approximately 6 months. She estimates that her ankles swell 70 to 80% of the time compared to 1 to 1.5 months ago, when she did not have any pain. She describes her symptoms as being more noticeable if she walks too fast or for too long, or if she tries to drink a whole glass of water without stopping. She does not feel dizzy or lightheaded, and she denies any history of recent heartburn or dyspnea.


PHYSICAL EXAM


Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.


Musculoskeletal
Exam of the right side of the chest reveals mild swelling to the right of the triceps, which is normal for someone in their mid-thirties. No pain to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities.
Bilateral right ankle swells are noted. There is mild left ankle swelling, mild plantarflexion, and decreased sensation in the right ankle.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-rays of the chest were obtained and reviewed today, 07/9/2021.
Impression: Significant right ventricular tachycardia.
Previous x-rays revealed a new worrisome heart murmur. Diana scott is wimperly at 120 cm2. She lost a little bit of weight, but she still weighs about 120 pounds. She has no evidence of any recent weight gain or changes in her diaphragm rhythm. Her diastolic rhythm is irregular. She experiences mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.


ASSESSMENT

• Status post coronary artery disease.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her findings are consistent with a new worrisome heart murmur. She will follow up with me in 2 weeks to assess her further symptoms. We will also discuss the possibility of performing a stress test on her heart to assess for any signs of aneurysm or atrial fibrinopathy. If she does not have these, we can consider performing a cardiac catheterization. The risk of this is low, but it would be a good idea to start her on amoxicillin 500 mg once a day for at least 6 weeks to see if it helps. She should also continue taking Tylenol 500 mg every 6 hours for pain. We also discussed the importance of weight loss and hydration.

[doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office . [patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Acne.
Mild to moderate acne.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kayla Ward is a 20-year-old female who presents for a new visit with her mother for acne. The onset of her acne began approximately 2 years ago. She has been using perc gel and washing regularly which has been somewhat helpful. She is a seventh grade student who lives with her parents, her sister, and her dog. She plays basketball, volleyball, and tap in school. She wears sunscreen in the summer with SPF 30. The patient states that she is starting to get some acne on the face, but not on the chest and back. She denies chest or back back pain. Her acne flares with her heavy sweating in the fall. She does not have a regular menstrual cycle, but reports that she has been menstruating for about 2 years.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Skin: Mild to moderate acne on the face, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
No additional skin concerns noted at this time.
Nontender to additional treatment options.
Bilateral breast implantation is normal.
Cervical: No tenderness or guarding.
Gastrointestinal: There is no tenderness to palpation of the colon or rectum.
VITALS REVIEWED

Exam of the abdomen reveals no enlarged lymph nodes.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray of the face, completed today, reveals mild-to-moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component, with some inflammatory component. The skin is relatively spared on the chest and back.
Impression: Clean skin with SPF 30 or higher on the trunk and extremities with scattered skin colored papules open and closed comedones and erythematous papules on the face primarily on the forehead and with also on the central cheeks and chin.
Echocardiogram: 0.1 mg/dL.


ASSESSMENT

Acne.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component. She has been using perc gels and facial scrubs for 2 years with mixed results. The most recent flare she experienced was probably due to increased sweating in the summer. The patient will follow up with me in 6 months to assess her progress.

Skin Care: I want the patient to start using a topical moisturizer every night. She should also continue to apply SPF 30 to her face at night.
The patient is currently not getting her periods. I will monitor her menstrual cycle.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder and elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. James is a new patient. He presents today for evaluation of left shoulder and left elbow pain, which has been present for about 5 months. He sustained the injury while going up the stairs. He states that his left arm and wrist took the brunt of the injury. He has always been a member of a gym and has been trying to keep up his 2-day-a-week routine, but the pain has worsened and he has not been able to lift more than 15-20 pounds. Over the past 2 weeks, he has stopped going to the gym and instead has been walking with his wife for 30 minutes every day. He denies any numbness or tingling, however, he states that he has tried ice and physical therapy, which does not provide him with relief. The patient denies any pain associated with his left wrist.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
No extra heart sounds.


Musculoskeletal
Exam of left shoulder reveals no tenderness, erythema, or deformity. Normal proximal and distal extremity strength. intact median, radial, ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees.
Examination of right shoulder reveals pain to palpation of the radial and ulnar sensory nerves, but no tingling or numbness.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Randy Gutierrez is a 20-year-old male who presents today for a physical evaluation. The patient has been feeling unwell for several days. His symptoms began around suppertime last night when he started to get a runny nose. He has also been pulling at his ears and has been going crazy rubbing his nose. His rectal temperature was 100.3 last night, which confirms a low grade fever. This morning, he ate 7 ounces of cereal and then drank another bottle of Tylenol. He is irritable and his sleep has been disrupted by his symptoms. His older sister has been recently diagnosed with a sinus infection.


objective_exam


The physical exam of Randy shows clear mucus in nose, throat, and ears.

Hematologic/lymphatics: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Neurological: Alert and oriented x3.
Psychological: In no apparent distress.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
VITALS REVIEWED

Integumentary: Grossly intact without focal neurologic findings.
Skin: No rash or ecchymosis.
Musculoskeletal: There is mild left bilaterally symmetric rash on his lower extremities.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray of the chest is reviewed and revealed a sinus infection.
Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.3.
Echocardiogram reveals a clear sinus cavity.
Impression: Randy is irritable and pulling on his ears.
Wet and waxy skin.
Abdominal x-ray demonstrates the presence of adenocarcinogenic anositis.
Lipid panel: Coughing.
Icy mucus.
Urinalysis reveals a cyst formation.


ASSESSMENT

• Status update.

Randy Gutierrez is a 21-year-old male who presents today with symptoms similar to a runny nose, congestion, fever, and a cough. His symptoms do not appear to be related to his previous symptoms. His rectal temperature was elevated to 101.3 on exam today, but this is consistent with a sinus infection. He has been compliant with his Tylenol and Motrin as needed today. We will continue to monitor his symptoms and call in any follow-up appointments.
• Additional questions were answered today. I want to know what his symptoms are likely related to and what his current symptoms are related to. I also wanted to know if there is anything else that could be contributing to his elevated fever and congestion. The most likely explanation for his fever is a build-up of fluid in his ears due to his ears being plugged up. I suspect this may be the source of his rash. I advised him to use baby lotion on his feet to try and help him breathe, and use a humidifier to keep his skin moist. He also declined his breakfast today, although I did offer him cereal. I recommended that he drink 1.5 ounces of milk this

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

New breast reduction consult.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Julia Jones is a 25-year-old female who presents for a new breast reduction consultation. She has a history of breast cancer in her family and has been considering a reduction for the past 6 or 7 years. She denies any prior knowledge of the procedure prior to today. The patient has been weighing approximately 20 pounds over the past few months and would like to lose another 10 pounds prior to the procedure. She states that she has been walking a lot at her desk and has noticed some neck and upper back pain. She experiences back pain when she is working or running. The pain has been present since she was in high school. She saw a chiropractor for her back pain and denies taking any pain medication for it. She also reports experiencing numbness and tingling in her hands and numbness in her breasts, sometimes in the hands and nipples, and rashes underneath her breasts that she suspects could be related to her breasts being sweaty. She reports that her breasts are always sweaty and she feels like her activities are limited because of the size. She wears a G-cup bra and has experienced back pain in the past 5
PHYSICAL EXAM


The ECOG performance status today is grade 0.
Breast: Breast density, breast tenderness to palpation, nipple pain to light touch, skin to skin contact.

Pelvic
Hematologic/lymphatics: There are no palpable masses, but there is some skin thickening at the nipples which may be caused by ecchymosis.
Neurological/Psychological: Mild cyanosis of the bilateral lower extremities.
Skin on the right breast is supple and supple to auscultation, no rash.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray images of the breasts were obtained and reviewed today and reviewed in detail. These images will be sent to the insurance company. Julia will be on Blue Cross Blue Shield plan in July. Julia is 25 years old and has a history of breast cancer in her family. Julia and her husband accepted a new job. Julia wants to be on the new plan in the summer. Julia would like to lose about 20 more pounds. Julia hasn't had a mammogram in the past 6-7 years. Julia doesn't plan to have any children in the future.
ASSESSMENT

Breast reduction consult.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that breast reduction surgery is a common procedure performed every 6 to 8 weeks. We discussed the risks associated with this procedure, as well as the possible complications associated with it. I recommended that the patient obtain a local anesthetic prior to the procedure. She will follow up with me afterwards to assess her level of relief.
INSTRUCTIONS
The patient will follow-up with me after the operation.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up of Prednisone.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Jazz Gomez is a 61-year-old female who presents today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis. The patient was last seen in clinic 3 months ago, at which time they were discussing decreasing her prednisone dose and increasing her methotrexate dose. She is currently on 1 dose of both. There were a couple of days in which she took the second dose due to increased joint pain in her feet and lower extremity numbness. Initially, when she received her covid shots, she was told that the drug could interfere with the vaccine, so she did not take the vaccine until a week later. She has a desk job, so her feet tend to hurt more when she is moving around. She used to see her podiatrist once a week for pain management of her feet. She also developed a rash on her nails, which the patient suspects to be related to the covid. The rash has been present for a long time. She reports that she has been wearing her shoes and socks without socks. She denies any pain sensitivity.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Pleasant disposition today.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.


Musculoskeletal
Exam indicated good range of motion in all 4 quadrants of the right upper extremity, including the bilateral lower extremities, without pain to palpation.
Bilateral right and left lower extremity pain.
Cervical
No tenderness, guarding, or guarding of the cervical spine.
Gastrointestinal
No hernia, periumbilical tenderness.
VITALS REVIEWED.

objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

Hemoglobin A1c 8.
Impression: Significant reductions in the prednisone and increased the methotrexate dose.
IMPRESSION: Mild-to-moderate arthritis in the arthritic joints with good range of motion and good rheumatoid arthritis.
Peripheral candidiasis.
X-ray of the right knee is consistent with psoriatic arthritis. There is no evidence of any significant changes in the joint aches and joint flexibility.
Prednisone is a high-risk medication. It is possible that it could interfere with the vaccine.


ASSESSMENT

• Status quo.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have recommended that we continue to treat her with the current regimen of prednisone and methotrexate. She has also been provided with a referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation. I recommended that she obtain a corticosteroid injection today. She will follow up with me in 3 months to check on her progress. We will also continue to monitor her bruising.
INSTRUCTIONS

Follow-up recommended.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney ultrasound.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kelly Wood is a 39-year-old female who presents today for a renal ultrasound because of hematuria. She is an established patient with a family history of kidney stones and a history of digestive tract disease. The patient states that she has been experiencing episodes of bright red urine for the past 6 weeks. She states that last week she was constantly having to pee and her back pain was terrible. She denies any flank pain or tenderness in her lower back. She reports that after passing 2 kidney stones last week, her back has felt a lot better. She continues to take ALAvert 10 mg daily and has no drug allergies.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Genitourinary
Hematuria.
Respiratory
No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Bilateral right kidney sounds normal. No masses, masses, or hydronephrosis.
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Neck
No thyromegaly.
Pelvic
No hernia, periumbilical tenderness, or flank pain.
Exam of the left kidney, there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing.


RESULTS

Renal ultrasound images of the right and left kidneys were obtained and reviewed today. The right kidney is 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide, there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing, 533 ml prevoid and 0 ml post void. There is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact.
Impression: Right kidney 10 cm in Length by 5 cm Wide, there are no stones, masses, or hydronephrosis.
Imaging: White blood cell count 0.2, ph 5.5, and specific gravity 1.2.
X-ray of the left kidney reveals no abnormalities.


ASSESSMENT

Kidney stone, left kidney.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. She should continue to limit her sodium intake to 10 mg daily, limit her dairy intake to 1/2 cup daily, and reduce the amount of red meat, poultry, fish, and pork that she eats. We also discussed the importance of avoiding triggers for kidney stones, such as over-indulgence, caffeine, alcohol, and vitamin D, as well as the risk of developing kidney stones in combination with other conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease, high blood pressure, and polycystic kidney disease. The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan. She will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on her progress.
